Hi every body
As you said, I studied wesley tutorial (Part I), times and ti=
mes and tried to learn more about C#, Class, Interface, ... and now, I am i=
mplementing my project (Racing Car).
I added 3 references to my project: lo=
g4net, SharpNeatDomains, SharpNeatLib
but I have error in :
using SharpNeat=
.Core;
using SharpNeat.Phenomes;=C2=A0
and etc!
and C# could not find these=
 name spaces.

would you please tell me more about its APIs: IBlackBox, ...=


To determine number of input and outputs, I changed their values in Tic-T=
ac_toeExperiments.cs, is it correct?
Where can I evaluate phenomes? (My fit=
ness function is based on outputs)

Adele



______________________________=
__
 From: Wesley Tansey <tansey@...>
To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
Sent: Thu=
rsday, December 8, 2011 12:05 PM
Subject: Re: [neat] NEAT for beginners
 

=
=C2=A0 
Adele,

It's certainly not necessary to understand the entire Sharp=
NEAT framework's implementation. You simply need to understand the top-leve=
l API, which is what I tried to explain in part 1 of the tutorial (http://w=
ww.nashcoding.com/2010/07/17/tutorial-evolving-neural-networks-with-sharpne=
at-2-part-1/). I'm not sure what other advice I could give there.

The best=
 thing to do is probably to just dive in. Start implementing your project a=
nd then if you can't figure out something specific, like your project isn't=
 compiling or the results hint at a bug, then ask the group here again.

We=
sley


On Thu, Dec 8, 2011 at 1:29 AM, adeleh ebrahimi <adlh_ebrahimi@yahoo=
.com> wrote:

 
>=C2=A0 
>Wesley,
>I took a look your tutorials before, The=
y are helpful, but for understanding them, =C2=A0I know I should get more e=
xperience with C#, and Now, I am doing it.
>I want to use NEAT for implemen=
ting my game project, would you please help me? which parts of NEAT are mor=
e important? which classes or libraries should I refer to study first? Is t=
here some order to learning? Is it necessary to learn all of SharpNEAT clas=
ses and codes? and so on...
>
>
>regards
>Adele
>
>________________________=
________
> From: Wesley Tansey <tansey!
@...>
>To: neat@yahoogroups.com =

>Sent: Wednesday, December 7, 2011 7:26 PM
>
>Subject: Re: [neat] NEAT for=
 beginners
>
>
>
>=C2=A0 
>I hope my tutorial series is helpful.=C2=A0I'm n=
ot sure that SharpNEAT is something a C# novice wants to dive into, to be h=
onest. If you simply want to get a project of your own up and running, then=
 following the tutorials will certainly help you do that.=C2=A0If you're lo=
oking for more insight into how the NEAT algorithm itself is implemented, a=
s it sounds like Adele is, then I would really not recommend SharpNEAT.=C2=
=A0
>
>
>The SharpNEAT framework is huge, the modularity of it can make it =
intimidating, and there are tons of low-level optimizations Colin has made =
that obscure things.=C2=A0If you do not feel confident in C#, but you wish =
to implement/understand a C# version of NEAT, then my suggestion would be t=
o first get more experience with C#. It's a simple enough language that any=
one with an OO background can pick it up quickly.
>
>
>As Drew mentioned, t=
here are implementations available in almost every language now, so if you'=
re strong in another language, it may be a better move to look at that vers=
ion. Ken has a list of different implementations available here:=C2=A0http:=
//www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software
>
>
>
>
>Wesley
>
>
>
>On Wed, Dec 7, =
2011 at 8:11 AM, Drew Kirkpatrick <drew.kirkpatrick@...> wrote:
>
>Ad=
ele,
>>
>>Sorry for the confusion, I thought you were trying to find=C2=A0m=
ore C++
>>NEAT examples. I'm afraid I'm a lowly C/C++ coder, and don't know=

>>anything really about C#. I believe the SharpNEAT C# version is one of
>=
>the more polished NEAT libraries.
>>
>>There's a 3 part tutorial using the=
 C# version starting here that might help:
>>http://www.nashcoding.com/2010=
/07/17/tutorial-evolving-neural-networks-with-sharpneat-2-part-1/
>>
>>That=
 might help a bit. If you have problems with going through the C#
>>code, t=
he python version might help. From what I understand, python is
>>a very in=
tuitive language. I'm not sure if they've released any code
>>yet. There's =
also the Java version.
>>
>>Sorry I wasn't more help. Good luck!
>>
>>-Drew=

>>
>>
>>On Wed, Dec 7, 2011 at 2:44 AM, adeleh ebrahimi <adlh_ebrahimi@yah=
oo.com> wrote:
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Drew,
>>> Thank you!
>>>
>>> I chose Mr. Boo=
kland book just because of its easy and simple codes, but I am working in t=
he area of =C2=A0"Games", and I think Bookland implementation is =C2=A0not =
a proper choice.
>>> =C2=A0I want to implement my project with =C2=A0a Visu=
al Programming language, maybe "C#"!, but As I said I do not have enough ex=
perience in C# and I could not understand some of C# codes of NEAT implemen=
tation. So I need a simple example.
>>>
>>> Adele
>>>
>>> _________________=
_______________
>>> From: Drew Kirkpatrick <drew.kirkpatrick@...>
>>
=
>>> To: neat@yahoogroups.com
>>> Sent: Tuesday, December 6, 2011 6:22 PM
>>=
> Subject: Re: [neat] NEAT for beginners
>>>
>>>
>>> Adele,
>>>
>>> I also =
started off from Mat Buckland's book, and have been working with a modified=
 version of his implementation. If you're particular about sticking with hi=
s implementation and C++ (his is a relatively simple implementation of NEAT=
 from what I understand) I can send you my code if you want (buggy work in =
progress).
>>>
>>> It's not a simple example at all (competitive coevolutio=
n), but it would give you some code examples and bug fixes to Mat Buckland'=
s original implementation (mine is a Linux port). Probably only useful to y=
ou for looking at the changes I made to Mr. Buckland's code, but that would=
 be easy as most of the code is the same, and the classes retained their na=
mes from those described in his book.
>>>
>>> You might want to start with =
getting his minesweeper (was that it?) example application running, and try=
 putting in some of the bug fixes folks have recommended in his implementat=
ion (I think I can help find those). Once you have that working, you might =
want to try the XOR test, and perhaps pole balancing. I believe those are c=
ommon tasks to undertake.
>>>
>>> Let me know if you want any code, or have=
 any questions I might be able to help with. I'm afraid I'm far from a NEAT=
 guru, but I don't think too many folks are working with Mat Buckland's imp=
lementation now. I think that's a great book, and that chapter helped me co=
nsiderably in getting started working with NEAT.
>>>
>>>
>>> -Drew
>>>
>>> =
On Tue, Dec 6, 2011 at 2:01 AM, adeleh ebrahimi <adlh_ebrahimi@...> w=
rote:
>>>
>>>
>>> Hi everybody
>>> I am new in learning NEAT. I studied Mr.=
 Stanley paper, =C2=A0titled "evolving Neural Networks through Augmenting T=
opologies" and
>>> Now, I am studying last chapter of Mr. Buckland book - "=
AI techniques for Game Programming".
>>>
>>> But I need to know more about =
NEAT implementation with an example. Is it possible to introduce me a prope=
r and simple example with its tutorial. Unfortunately I don`t have enough e=
xperience in C#.
>>>
>>> Sincerely
>>> Adele
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>
>>

    <div>
      
      
  =
    <div>I hope my tutorial series is helpful. I'm not sure that Sharp=
NEAT is something a C# novice wants to dive into, to be honest. If you simp=
ly want to get a project of your own up and running, then following the tut=
orials will certainly help you do that. If you're looking for more ins=
ight into how the NEAT algorithm itself is implemented, as it sounds like A=
dele is, then I would really not recommend SharpNEAT. </div>
<div>
<br=
></div><div>The SharpNEAT framework is huge, the modularity of it can make =
it intimidating, and there are tons of low-level optimizations Colin has ma=
de that obscure things. If you do not feel confident in C#, but you wi=
sh to implement/understand a C# version of NEAT, then my suggestion would b=
e to first get more experience with C#. It's a simple enough language that =
anyone with an OO background can pick it up quickly.<div>

<br></div><div>A=
s Drew mentioned, there are implementations available in almost every langu=
age now, so if you're strong in another language, it may be a better move t=
o look at that version. Ken has a list of different implementations availab=
le here: http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software</div>

<div><br></d=
iv><div><br></div><div>Wesley<br><div><div><br><div>On Wed, Dec 7, 2011 at =
8:11 AM, Drew Kirkpatrick <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a rel=3D"nofollow" ymailto=
=3D"mailto:drew.kirkpatrick@..." target=3D"_blank" href=3D"mailto:dre=
w.kirkpatrick@...">drew.kirkpatrick@...</a>></span> wrote:<b=
r>

<blockquote style=3D"border-left:1px #ccc solid;">Adele,<br>
<br>
Sorry=
 for the confusion, I thought you were trying to find more C++<br>
NEA=
T examples. I'm afraid I'm a lowly C/C++ coder, and don't know<br>
anything=
 really about C#. I believe the SharpNEAT C# version is one of<br>
the more=
 polished NEAT libraries.<br>
<br>
There's a 3 part tutorial using the C# v=
ersion starting here that might help:<br>
<a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_bl=
ank" href=3D"http://www.nashcoding.com/2010/07/17/tutorial-evolving-neural-=
networks-with-sharpneat-2-part-1/">http://www.nashcoding.com/2010/07/17/tut=
orial-evolving-neural-networks-with-sharpneat-2-part-1/</a><br>


<br>
That=
 might help a bit. If you have problems with going through the C#<br>
code,=
 the python version might help. From what I understand, python is<br>
a ver=
y intuitive language. I'm not sure if they've released any code<br>
yet. Th=
ere's also the Java version.<br>
<br>
Sorry I wasn't more help. Good luck!<=
br>
<br>

> I also s=
tarted off from Mat Buckland's book, and have been working with a modified =
version of his implementation. If you're particular about sticking with his=
 implementation and C++ (his is a relatively simple implementation of NEAT =
from what I understand) I can send you my code if you want (buggy work in p=
rogress).<br>


><br>
> It's not a simple example at all (competitive=
 coevolution), but it would give you some code examples and bug fixes to Ma=
t Buckland's original implementation (mine is a Linux port). Probably only =
useful to you for looking at the changes I made to Mr. Buckland's code, but=
 that would be easy as most of the code is the same, and the classes retain=
ed their names from those described in his book.<br>


><br>
> You mi=
ght want to start with getting his minesweeper (was that it?) example appli=
cation running, and try putting in some of the bug fixes folks have recomme=
nded in his implementation (I think I can help find those). Once you have t=
hat working, you might want to try the XOR test, and perhaps pole balancing=
. I believe those are common tasks to undertake.<br>


><br>
> Let me=
 know if you want any code, or have any questions I might be able to help w=
ith. I'm afraid I'm far from a NEAT guru, but I don't think too many folks =
are working with Mat Buckland's implementation now. I think that's a great =
book, and that chapter helped me considerably in getting started working wi=
th NEAT.<br>


><br>
